G10.name: Alluvial graph

reading_principle.1: Each of the two parallel axis represents a set of data.
reading_principle.2: A line that represent interactions links elements from one category with elements from the other category.

G10.advantages: Show clearly a the evolution between a beginning and an ending situation.
G10.disadvantages: Becomes hard to read when there are too many fluxes, or where the axes are not clearly labelled.

G20.name: Bar graph

reading_principle.1: The length of each bar is proportionnal to the size of the category it represents.
reading_principle.2: Bars can be horizontal or vertical. Horizontal bars, for instance, are much more telling when a length is measured (life expectancy, distance, …).

G20.disadvantages: Becomes problematic to label when there is a huge number of categories : some categories may have to be grouped.

reading_principle.1: A geographical area is distorted and each sub-area (state, region, administrative division, …) is proportional to the corresponding quantity.
reading_principle.2: The sub-areas can be replaced by simple shapes such as circles, but their relative places should remain the same.

advantages.1: Display a geographical distribution and quantify elements on each area.
advantages.2: Two parameters can be displayed at once if necessary, depending on the size of the symbol and its colour.

disadvantages.1: Can become overcharged there is a big amount of data
disadvantages.2: Can become misleading when the disposition of the shapes is too different from geographical reality.

G50.name: Chloropleth map
G50.reading_principle: The importance of a phenomenon is colour-coded within geographical areas (states, regions, administrative divisions, …).
G50.advantages: Compare distributions in different geographical areas.
G50.disadvantages: Can become hard to read if there is a lot of data.

G55.name: Circo
G55.reading_principle: Interactions  are represented by arcs that linking elements disposed on the periphery of a circle.
G55.advantages: Interactions are emphasized and relative importances can be easily compared.
G55.disadvantages: Can become overcharged and hard to read when there is a big amount of data or when there are too many interactions !

G75.name: Dasymetric map
G75.reading_principle: A phenomenon is quantified on a map with a colour coded scale. Geographical borders (for states, regions, administrative divisions,…) are drawn over the larger area.
G75.advantages: Show a distribution on a larger scale but keep geographical areas in mind as well.
G75.disadvantages: Finding an adequate colour scale to quantify all variations can be difficult.

G90.name: Dot-density map
G90.reading_principle: Each dot represents an occurrence of a phenomenon or defines a fixed quantity on a certain spot.
G90.advantages: Link a precise quantity to an area and show it on a map.
G90.disadvantages: Becomes unadapted when there are too many occurrences in a very small range.

G95.name: Double-sided bar graph

reading_principle.1: The length of each bar is proportionnal to the size of the category it represents.
reading_principle.2: Data can either be broken down into time intervalls (like histograms) or into different categories (like bar charts).

G95.advantages: Compare data to a quantified objective.
G95.disadvantages: Does not detail data repartition within the chosen time intervals.

G100.name: Elevation map
G100.reading_principle: Data is representend on a geographical area in a continuous way : it is quantified by its altitude on a map.
G100.advantages: Compare distributions in different geographical areas.
G100.disadvantages: Unadapted for a situation where there are few variations within the data : the differences are hardly percievable.

G115.name: Flow map
G115.reading_principle: Flows are superposed on a geographically accurate map.
G115.advantages: Show accurately movements or fluxes between geographical areas.
G115.disadvantages: Can become overcharged and hard to read when there is a big amount of data.
